text: Was hesitant to go to dandelion for food, only ever been for late night bar scene. Was very pleasantly surprised by the food. Service at the bar was friendly and helpful as well. I do wish for late night that the downstairs would turn down the music. Some people want to dance and have that loud scene, maybe keep that upstairs. Sometimes I want to hang out, sit down, chat with friends, it would be nice to have both in one bar. Dandelion has that opportunity, having 2 floors, to appeal to both crowds!

I just grabbed a quick lunch to take back to my desk...the soup of the day was delightful!! Sweet potatoes pur√©ed to perfection with fresh, cracked pepper and ginger!! It was amazing!! I complimented it with a fresh side salad (spring mix with cumbers & cherry tomatoes) and the best balsamic vinaigrette dressing! This was a refreshing and wonderful lunch! I will definitely return!

We were optimistic for Sunday Brunch based on four overall Yelp stars, but this ended up being one of our worst dining out experiences. Ever.  I ordered the crab cakes Benedict, and I didn't know you could make crab taste bad, but they did. It was dry, old, and chewy. The hollandaise wasn't bad, but there was so little of it you almost didn't know it was there. I ordered a side of grits for $2.50, figuring they'd be worth the hefty price tag, but they were stale, tasteless, and so old and overcooked they were just a homogenized mush. It was a disgrace to one of the South's most sacred dishes.  Service was almost nonexistent. I had to ask another waitress for a refill of water because we never saw ours after we were seated.   Bonus? The waitress of the adjacent table sprayed cleaner in my direction, splashing me with chemicals that, judging by the immediate burning sensation, weren't meant to be applied directly to human skin.  All in all, the tab was skyrocket high for the quality, what service there was came with a frown or a spritz of chemicals, and we won't be back.

Portions are small, but unique and delicious. You won't be getting american-style huge plates, but every dish will be a complete treat. Some chefs get adventurous in a bad way, but this menu is definitely a winner.   wild mushrooms: incredible taste, cooked perfectly chicken wings: better than average, but this dish really excelled due to the custom ranch. I didn't know ranch could be made to taste like that! lamb lollipops: small portion (half-rack is two ribs), but the cherry sauce is insane. The lamb meat was good by itself, fairly little seasoning so you're mainly getting lamb meat and a really tasty sauce buttered scallops: 3 scallops to a plate, but they are incredible. Quite buttery, but the low # of scallops keeps you from being overwhelmed. They are cooked quite well, not soggy at all  Our bill would have been ~$40 for these 4 dishes, but with a coupon came out to $20.  I would definitely go again

I had heard some good things from someone I know - after my experience there this weekend and checking back with that person it appears they had been coming here a while.  Apparently they no longer go here often anymore because of how overcrowded it is now.  They are now charging a $5 cover for guys - which covers exactly nothing because there is no live music.  Rather than switch to "one in, one out" the owner just lets in as many people that show up.  It was literally impossible to move upstairs and not much better downstairs.  Good luck getting a drink.  I can't speak to the staff but had a brief interaction with the owner and he was one of the rudest people I have ever met.  Talking down to people and acting like it was a gift to be allowed in the bar.  Charlotte has too many good places to visit to waste time/money here.

I would give this place 3-1/2 stars, and choose 3 because it already has lots of higher ratings.  It is a busy place with a great ambiance on Friday evening.  Downstairs at least it feels more like a bar than a restaurant - minimal decor, rustic, and loud.  The service was perfect, as were the drinks.  The selection of beers on tap is excellent, and there was a good selection of wine choices on a chalk board.  The idea that the tapas-style menu is not for the hungry is specious:   Two of us shared four plates and left stuffed (the waitress recommended sharing 2-3 plates per person).  The "warm roasted olives" are for the serious olive lover,  I like olives and my wife loves olives but we could hardly make a dent in the big pile of olives they delivered.  They were very tasty, however.  The trio of spreads was good, although none of the spreads was exceptional.  "Ale simmered sausage bites" in a hot mustard sauce were tasty, but incredibly simple.  The Quattro Framiggio flatbread was the most ordinary; if there was truffle oil as advertised it was overwhelmed by the carmelized onions, and overall the flatbread did not seem to be freshly prepared.  Based on what we had and what we saw on the menu, I would say that the food offered is not as creative as the menu descriptions.  I come back to the conclusion that the Dandelion Market is more a bar than a restaurant.

Dandelion is a lot of fun when the upstairs turns into a dance club! When ever I have friends come into town, it's a favorite spot to check out. It just feels a little sketchy when they crank the table up to make room up stairs,  but its neat to see.

Good atmosphere, close downtown location, reasonably priced and straight forward wine list and solid food.  Started with the spinach and artichoke app which was one of the best I've had--fresh and more of a composite than your fast food Philadelphia variety found almost exclusively elsewhere.  That was accompanied by calamari which was cook just right.  I then moved onto the tuna as a main course and my friend the scallops; both solid choices.  I'd certainly return.  Oh, and the bartender, was great...solid service and just great personality...if I could only recall her name to ensure she got recognized.
Great food!  Reasonable price! Ate at the bar because it was packed on a Thursday night at 8! Bartender was very attentive even being busy!   Highly recommended

After driving past here a few times I really wanted to check it out because the interior looked really neat. When I looked online their menu looked delicious and I thought it'd be a great choice for me and my wife to go celebrate our anniversary; bad idea. First of all this place is not terrible. The food is fairly good, (ribs, crab/avocado stack, and butternut squash were good but the cheese board and southern caprese were disappointing) the beer is cold (my wife enjoyed her cocktail) and the service was exceptional. What ruined this place for me was the noise level, which was nauseatingly loud. All of the seating (including the bar) is in a small area so I understand it could be noisier than usual but they turn up the music and promote a louder atmosphere. Me and my wife could barely have a conversation and the party next to us was nearly screaming at each other. They had a game up on at the bar which encouraged a bunch of dudebros to constantly yell at the television. This was the first time I ever got a headache because of a noise level in a restaurant and it completely ruined the evening for me. Please don't advertise yourself as a "romantic" date night like you do on your website and then create a loud and obnoxious atmosphere like this.

Thus is just the place downtown needs. Great food , great price , great service. NOT pretentious. If u want a great place to eat and feel good, this is the place. Rustic feel but also contemporary feel. We had the sliders, lamb lollipops, greens beans, and cheese plate. Nothing was disappointing.  I would  definitely go back

I am picky about food. The Dandelion Market passed the test. I had prosciutto and baked mussels. Both excellent. The desert was a pleasant surprise. I can bake just about anything, so I am tough to satisfy. The apple ravioli succeeded. The right balance of softness and crispness, and the cinnamon sugar on top was just the cherry on the cake. Furthermore, the ice cream was really creamy and tasty (be careful with the ice cream you serve if you want to be appreciated, that can ruin an otherwise great pie!). And last but not least, the staff was nice too.
Love this place. The bartenders were good guys and happy to help you out. I didn't eat but the menu looks great and the prices seem reasonable.

Had some friends in town staying at The Dunhill Hotel uptown, they had already been to Harvest Moon Grille the night before, which was a bummer because I really want to try that place out. After some catching up and a couple of drinks from the hotel bar we all decided to walk around the block and give Dandelion Market a go.  My wife and I have been here before so we knew more or less what to expect.  For anyone who happens to still be reading....this place is a tapas style place with an abundance of selections to fit any picky eater's desires.  There were six of us and while we waited for a table to open up I wanted to show off the upstairs area which I think is a very cool spot with high ceilings, exposed brick, a nice bar, cozy seating selections and an interesting contraption hanging in the middle of the room that is used to raise and lower a huge dining table.  They have a great selection of local brews on tap. After a drink we headed back downstairs to our table. We ordered ALL of the following items: trio of spreads, southern caprese salad, flat bread, home made chips, buttered sauteed sea scallops, pan seared ahi tuna, crab cakes, dando ribs and grilled flat iron oscar. Carrot cake and peanut butter chocolate cake rounded out the feast.  A few things really stood out for me. The pimento cheese spread that came with the trio of spreads was fantastic. The home made chips were hot and absolutely delicious coupled with a brew. The grilled flat iron oscar was just mouth-watering good, nice rare steak covered with asparagus cream sauce.  Everyone in our party left a bit tipsy (thanks to the high alcohol content of the local brews) left with with a full stomach and left with a smile on our faces.   An all around great experience. I would definitely recommend Dandelion Market, for the atmosphere, the great selection of brews on tap, great menu and good, friendly service.

I've eaten here a few times with friends and I absolutely love it.   Grilled cheese with prosciutto and tomato is outstanding, and their hash browns with house made ketchup are spicy and wonderfully. The Bellini is not overly sweet and delicious.   Also I suggest the prosciutto Benny and the fresh fruit as a side. I was impressed that they didn't over or undercook the egg, it came out just right.  The Benny is a bit small so a small plate is the perfect complement for a full meal.   The service is excellent and their decor is so quaint. The Bloody Mary bar is on point with tons of options and their selection of draft local beers is pretty good. Love it here and I always recommend it for brunch to all.

Very cool, great space, tables well separated. Feels unique, charming, and hip. Excellent music.   As for the food, this place offers "small plates" - so it works like tapas. The shrimp and grits were very tasty, and the scallops were particularly delicious, with a pomegranate drizzle. The car bomb cupcake for dessert was also delightful - Guinness chocolate cupcake and an Irish whiskey caramel filling and baileys frosting.   For drinks, there's a wonderful bourbon/fig cocktail - makers mark and fig brown sugar simple syrup and an orange twist. Also interesting - all the wines are $25/bottle, and what you don't drink you can take home with you.
The cheeses, figs and meat platter were remarkable.

Good place to eat with a causal/upbeat atmosphere. Food was solid! Our table ended up getting - meatballs, mac-n-cheese, spinach & artichoke dip, fried calamari, sweet potato gnocchi and fried tomatoes.  Service was spot on and drinks were delicious!  I will definitely come back!

This bar is for people more in the early 20's, college kids on their parents couches, or technical college crowd  that like a crowded bar. Sometimes the crowd is trashy. I have not had the food, but I have gone for the bar scene, and I will not be returning.  I would go more in-depth about my experience, but afraid Yelp will screen my comment.   The DJ does NOT take requests.

Cute atmosphere! Go early if you want a table - it gets crowded fast. The small plates are great for a group of friends. I highly recommend any of their restaurant locations, and their catering is superb!

When we walked into Dandelion Market (Dang-delicious Market I should say), it was quite dark and so I wasn't really sure about it at first. We were escorted upstairs were it was much more open and brighter. They offer many different tapas style small plates to share with one another. I would say that Dandelion Market has the best Mac & Cheese of any place I have tried so far in Charlotte! Someone else ordered the lamb lollipops and the only bad thing about them was that we finished them off too fast! They were cooked very nicely and not overly cooked and full of flavor!   I'm not sure what time they stop serving food upstairs but as the night gets later, the upstairs becomes an extension of the downstairs bar. It was a place we enjoyed very much and hope to visit Dandelion Market again soon. Didn't see any Dandelion Market brush post but hope to give it a try next time we visit this place. Good job Dandelion Market, I'm really glad we ended up stopping in and not just passing it by!

Wow! That's my first and last impression. My two friends and I visited the Dandelion Market for our first time Sunday. The setting was cozy and cute, very nice atmosphere even though it was not very busy. We were greeted by a friendly face and seated in a table by the window we requested. Our server was so helpful and knowledgable about the dishes that we were confused about. She had made our experience really enjoyable.   I don't know what people don't understand about TAPAS - but that means small plates/portions - if you want a full sized entree go elsewhere. I on the other hand love Tapas style you get to try everything! And get stuffed.   For dinner we did the skewers, Mac and cheese, lamb lollipops, green beans, and pickles.  Oh my gosh! My senses went wild. The food was sooooo yummy! The meat dishes were tender. The Mac and cheese though simple - was delightful. The green beans were cooked perfectly.  Loved the pickles as well their ranch dipping sauce complimented them perfectly. Quality!! I really wanted to try more but we were stuffed the menu had a lot of options though, we will definitely be back.

Went there over the weekend for drinks. The place was very nice and the service was good. They had a nice selection of wines and beers. Unfortunately we did not to get eat because didn't have enough time but the dishes we some come out looked delicious.

Food, staff, environment all fit and are balanced for what they are trying to do.  l especially enjoyed the fantastically huge plate of warm chocolate brownie covered in carmel and served with vanilla bean ice cream. The Lamb lollipops with cherry glaze are unique and made to perfection and the chorizo stuffed pepper appetizer is also a must have.
Lighting and noise level could use some work downstairs. Very pleased with the food and service overall.

Stopped in for the first time tonite after the Hornets game...or lack thereof. I gotta say, the food here is outstanding. My wife and I ordered 5 or 6 items from their tapas-style menu to share. We tried the prosciutto crostini which is just melt-in-your-mouth goodness. The seared scallops with arugula was great as well as the mac and cheese which comes piping hot in its own bakeware. Good selection of drinks as well, I had the "winter-fashioned".  It was very crowded and loud as it was getting late on a saturday, so I would recommend going earlier if you dont wanna deal with that. All in all, excellent choice and we will be back.

My husband and I came here with 2 friends for a Sunday hangover brunch. We walked in, easily got a table and sat down to wait and wait and wait and wait. It took over 20 minutes before the waitress took our order then we continued to wait and wait and wait some more. 55 minutes of waiting after we placed our order before the first plate of food arrived! We ordered 2 omelettes, French toast sticks and a hangover hash. Everything was good but definitely not worth a 55 minute wait!

I thoroughly enjoyed my meal at this establishment. The ambiance is really nice here at night. They have a bar and a few televisions where we were able to watch a few of the college football games but doesn't give off a sports bar vibe at all. The wait staff were very accommodating and attentive. My brother and I ordered four small shareable plates and we were stuffed. With just two people, we probably only needed 2 to 3 of the plates. We had the fried calamari, meatballs marinara, shrimp & grits, and grilled chicken wings. The chipotle brown sugar glaze on the wings was superb. They were so good. The calamari was honestly some of the best calamari I've ever tasted and the aioli sauce with it was so good. The shrimp and grits were really good too. The meatballs marinara was okay. The marinara sauce was a little muted for my liking. Overall, we had an amazing dining experience and will definitely be back when visiting Charlotte.

Tapas were OK but a little expensive for the quality.  The atmosphere was bar-like but fun.  The best part and worth a trip alone: the brownie & ice cream with salted caramel.  I'll be back but just for dessert and an Irish coffee.

Went here with a girlfriend for dinner. Being from out of town, I had called ahead of time to see about making reservations for a Saturday night at 7:30. I was told they only made reservations for large parties but that I should have no problem getting in at that time. So when I was told upon arriving that it would be an hour wait, I was a little disappointed. The hostess was very unapologetic about it and in fact, seemed like she was having a bad night. We tried to wait around the bar area but we really felt like we were in the way. Also felt like we were the oldest people in the place- we are in our early 50's. This is definitely a younger crowd place. It was so noisy- one girl was so loud, you literally could not hear anyone else. One of the hostesses came to get us and told us our table was ready. As she began to seat us, at a table for 6- with 6 menus- I realized she might be confused. Sure enough, she apologized and told us this was not our table. We had to stand around some more. When the party of 6 did not show up, the pulled the table apart and seated us again. When my friend tried to thank the hostess, she said rudely, "I need your beeper"- which I had already given to the other hostess.  But the food saved the day! We tried the shrimp bruschetta- it was the best dish of the night. Aldo had the trio of hummus, red pepper spread and delicious pimento cheese with warm pita bread. The crab and avocado salad was good but needed a little more seasoning. We also had the gnocchi with winter vegetables and the black bean burger. The gnocchi were cut a little too large for my liking and didn't care for the black bean burger. It was heavy and dry. Not sure I would go back for just a party of two. the food was great but the hostess should be ashamed of herself. You are in customer service, girl. Shame on you.
I love this place. Yummy small plates, love  the overall atmosphere. I will never turn down going to dandelion.
My wife and I ate here this past weekend and really enjoyed the food.  They also have a nice selection of beer.   Definitely worth checking out if you are in the area.

My girlfriend and I went to this place because we heard such good reviews. We walked in on Saturday afternoon and there were a few people there so we were seated fairly quick. Thats the highlight. The waitress took a while to get to us. I am not sure if she was the only one there but if thats the case they need to hire more people. When she finally came over we both order the scrambled eggs w/ potatoes and peppers. We thought this would fill us up. When it came out the whole thing was inside of a very small cast iron skillet. I was speechless. I decided to give it a chance and boy was I disappointed. Flavorless, and way too hot. No amount of salt or pepper would save it.  My girlfriend was still hungry so she ordered a side of potatoes.  She said they were okay, but I did not try them. I was too mad about this "culinary crime" that had been perpetrated on me.  The decor was even questionable.  I have no clue what this place is trying to be. Is it a bar, a restaurant, a lounge, an eclectic hangout for non-conformist. Whatever it is it is not for me and I will not be going back.

I'm struggling with the fact that I've given Dandelion Market just 3 stars.  The service here is great.  It is, in fact, some of the best service I've had in a Charlotte restaurant.  Each server has been friendly and competent.  The beer selection here is solid.  I am impressed that they have a good number of regional craft brews on tap here.   I love tapas-style dining.  I would prefer to graze than to just put my head in a feed bag and chow down on some oversized portion of something.  The quality of food preparation here is pretty consistent.  There are some menu items that I have not liked, but it was simply personal taste and not due to anything going awry in the kitchen.  Here's my "gripe" with Dandelion:  I've been 5 or 6 times now and have eaten nearly everything on the menu.  Some things I want to eat a second or third time, but I no longer sit at home and think that I'm dying to eat at DM because I haven't tried "x" yet.  Again, this is not because the food tastes bad.  The food is great.  I would just like to see some menu rotation.  But perhaps there is rotation and I've just missed it.    If you've never eaten at Dandelion Market I highly recommend it.  It's a great restaurant and with some seasonal menu changes I'd give it 4 or 5 stars.
Great food, great drinks and even has Groupons occasionally. Weekends after 10 the upstairs turns into a dance floor.

Cool place - serves a young and hip crowd.  Lots of small groups.   Good and friendly service.   So-so food.  We had five dishes to share.  Green beans, ahi tuna, sliders, caprese salad, and prosciutto.  Nothing stood out. Ahi tuna was the best and sliders was weakest (beef had funny flavor but dish looked appetizing).    Would go back with a group as atmosphere was fun.

The food is pretty good, nothing spectacular....  We had the cheese board and the charcuterie for starters - nothing amazing here, but still good.  The prosciutto crostini and scallops were amazing!  The mussels were over cooked, but the sauce was a hit!  The mac-n-cheese was tasty, we think there was a hint of truffle oil.  The ambiance at night is dark and pub-like.  It is a little noisy, but not loud.  This is a great place for meeting friends for an evening out.  The wine selection is broad and reasonably priced.  The bar has quite a few taps with good beers and every liquor imaginable.  To sum it up, this place is good for a night out with friends who appreciate quality food and good drinks.
Good tapas, small plates. Great brunch and decent lunch. Sometimes slow. Also great place for drinks.

Stopped in for a bite while walking through Taste of Charlotte. Did not realize until ordering it was a "tapas-style" small dish menu. I ordered the special - lobster and asparagus mac and cheese. It was delicious! and very filling even for a "small" dish. In the interest of trying something new, ordered the Big Boss D'Icer...a local brew from Raleigh - also delicious. Would definitely recommend Dandelion Market. Nice ambiance and friendly wait staff.

Stopped in for a beer and an couple plates. I ordered a beer that was listed as a pint on the menu. It came in a 9oz glass. When I asked about this I was told the menu is incorrect and that high ABV beers are served in smaller glasses. The beer was 7.5%. No apology from the bartender. No effort to give me what I ordered.    I decided not to order another round.
Love the vegetarian options. Very friendly staff. Good selection of beers on tap.
Great selection of Tapas! Drinks were great and the staff was really friendly! Even our kids loved the choices!

The word I would choose to describe this dimly lit menagerie of goodness is fantastic!!I have been here a few times and have never regretted the decision to walk through the double glass doors. The servers are not always very friendly and peppy (which may be the point), but they are always efficient, polite, and do their job well. The calamari with the lemon garlic aioli is top-notch! Actually, all of it is good but maybe stay away from the flatbread...not worth the dollars or the space in your gut that can be filled with something oh so much better from their menu. The Tuesday night $15 bottle of wine is well worth the addition to your small plate selection. 5 stars for sure!!!
Worst service I have ever experienced. It took two hours plus to get my food. The only good thing was that there is no way to get over served. The food once it came was marginal at best.
One of my favorite restaurants in Charlotte.  Food is always on point and I love the deal on bottles of wine.  Great atmosphere and location!

This is tough to review because on one hand, the space is great. The upstairs is big and open, while the downstairs is more laid back and intimate. Both rooms have good rustic/pub/wooden d√©cor. As expected, a great beer selection.   Here's where it disappointed. The food was just terrible. Maybe it was bad night? Also, the upstairs becomes a hip-hoppy club after 11 and it's packed. Maybe that's what some are looking for, but it threw me off a bit.

I travel into Charlotte and this has become my default go-to location. Great selection of beer. $8 flights of 3 craft beers. Mon is pint night with $3.50 beers and Tue is wine night with $15 bottles.   The menu is impressive and the dishes are very good. I tried a half portion of the lamb lollipops (2 pieces). It was very good, a little on the salty side but balanced out the sweet. I also tried the chorizo stuffed poblano pepper. This was a little less salty and very spicy. Only order you can handle the heat. Brussel sprouts, tuna credo, ahi tuna are all very good. Usually, a couple of small plates are good.   Overall, the food is excellent and very well priced. I even got a free beer at the end my first time because one of the rotating beer tap breweries was there and had a limited edition beer.
Food, drinks and staff were awesome! Had black bean sliders, shrimp and grits ( off the chain!), salad with goat cheese, sea scallops! Cocktails made perfect!

I can't believe have not reviewed Dandelion yet, as it is one of my regular go to places.  Perfect for happy hour drinks, or a meal.   Casual, pub-style eatery but the menu is anything but average pub&grub. Brunch is my favorite here thanks to the tasty Migas and bloody mary bar.  Not traditional tapas, but certainly small plate style.  Good for sharing. Full list of $25 bottles of wine. Last visit each of us ( 4 people) chose one item  and it was perfect for a late night post-movie bite.  The service is consistently friendly and attentive.

One star is too many for this restaurant.  We have tried it 3 times and one time for brunch was just ok; the food is not very hot; don't know if it is pre-made or just sits there too long.  But today we had brunch there again and I have been in the bathroom ever since returning home & it cost $50.00 for 3 people - if it was good that would be a good deal but to make people sick is a bad thing!  My husband also does not feel well.  Only my daughter who had a sandwich is ok.  This is just a bar! Will never return!

Went to the Dandelion Market because of the good reviews. I don't know if the people had too much to drink or have low standards, but I was not impressed. The atmosphere is drab black and dark. It is noisy as it has nothing to absorb the noise, the floors are wooden and it is sparsley furnished (we were upstairs). We were trying to eat the overpriced tapas and have a decent conversation with friends when all of the sudden the employees started making a huge scene while they dramatically lifted a long table off of the floor to the ceiling I guess to make room for all the partiers that they expected to come into the place, with no where to sit, standing room only. The food was so so. I couldn't believe they had mac and cheese as a tapas. It was like the frozen Stouffers kind. There were a few good ones, but for the most part, I felt we had to order 10 tapas to feed the four of us, the servings were so small. Not a very good wine selection. It is more of a bar than a place to go and eat and have a conversation with friends. I prefer to walk around the corner and go to the Wooden Vine for my wine and tapas with friends.

I came here with my husband on a Friday night. We were seated right away, and the service was attentive. The food was just uninspired though. We got a cheese board and charcuterie board to start. The charcuterie was very tastey, but the cheese was boring. After that, we had the crab and avocado salad and the shrimp bruschetta.  Everything tasted fresh, but was lacking in flavor. That was sort of the theme of the meal. Nothing was outright bad, but nothing made me want to come back.

This was our first time trying Dandelion and we had a wonderful experience.   We were using a living social deal so I was not sure what to expect with the service.  I've been to places before that provided mediocre service because I had a coupon or deal.  This was not the case with Dandelion.  Our waitress (who's name I unfortunately can not remember) walked us through the menu, how the deal worked and provided suggestions on how to make the most of our evening.  The food was incredible and the wine, beer and cocktail menu was extensive.  It was a fantastic night out and I can't say enough about how great of a time we had.

My husband and I stopped in on our way from Charlotte to Brevard.  What an amazing find!  The food was excellent (so much so that I'm writing this review a month after our meal!) and the service was friendly, knowledgable and quick.  You cannot go wrong here and you can certainly trust the staff to steer you in the right direction.  The fried pickles and marinated seared flatiron steak are to die for!  Make this a destination - you won't regret it!!!  PS - I don't drink beer but my husband loved the selection.

Instead of hitting the standard chain food fare we wanted to take a couple of our friend's visiting from out of town to a local restaurant.   Our second visit to the Dandelion Market for dinner on a Friday night was a different experience than the first.  After our first visit we played a little safe by selecting some items we thought one couldn't really go wrong with.  First, "Baked Potato" Croquettes.  No complaints.  Well cooked, lightly brown, fresh oil.  We went again for the Grilled Steak Skewers.  This time cooked perfectly.  Finally, the risotto special.  I wish this could be a standard item.    Lastly, our friends wanted one more item to top off their dinner so they inquired about the calamari.  The waitress told us very honestly, it completely depends on whose cooking it.  Indeed!  That could certainly explain the vast difference between the two visits.  The calamari did not disappoint.  This time as we watched food come out to the tables around us we actually wanted what they ordered!  Including the dessert which we regretfully didn't have room for.  Next time!  It would probably be in the best interest of the owners to have their best chef spend some time training the others to share the love and deliver a consistent product every time.  Consistently good food is what people are looking for in a restaurant!

I had heard so much about this place before my visit with 7 other friends a couple weeks ago.  I can tell you Dandelion Market certainly lived up to all my expectations from the service and cozy atmosphere to the delicous menu. I love the small, "tapas" style entrees.    You can order several selections, share with friends (my group all ordered different selections and passed them around.) I always enjoy eating small portions and feeing satisfied, not over fed.  I already had the procuitto crostini in mind.  Boy was it delicious, salty and sweet and creamy, too.  Our server stayed attentive to our table, was very helpful explaining the menu and kept the drinks coming.  I really like the carafes of water on the table, so that your water glass in never empty and you don't have to keep asking your server for more.  Great idea!    I also recommend the steak skewers and the spicy prawns and flatbreads.  The guiness  (sp) brownie is delicous.  Great beer selection too.     I loved the exposed brick interior and over stuffed chairs tucked in one nook,  great for having drinks and conversation.   All in all a great night and I hope to return again soon.

I didn't get the bartenders name but it was a Tuesday happy hour and he took the time to go over the drink and food menus with us. Quick service, tasty food (Apple salad n a flatbread pizza), great beer and wine selections. The small crowd was after-work, late 20s early 30s. Would definitely go back!

Decided to try this place out because of other reviews on Yelp. I enjoyed the atmosphere and the food. The waitress was great, too. So as far as food goes, there was 3 of us in our group. We were there for dinner and ordered a bottle of wine (all the bottles are $25!). We started with the cheese plate, the antipasto plate and the roasted red pepper and artichoke dip. We all agreed that the dip was really tasty and left none in the bowl. The cheese plate offered 3 different cheeses, nothing extraordinary but not bad. The antipasto had salami, prosciutto, sausage and pepperoni. Here again, nothing extraordinary but definitely tasty.  Next course we ordered the chicken roulade, ahi tuna, steak skewers and ribs. The ribs were fall off the bone, really good! The ahi tuna was my next favorite. The steak was a bit tough but had a good flavor. And finally the chicken roulade was just a bit overcooked (but anything with goat cheese in it is good to me).  We finished with a cheese fondue (sounds silly now, but we also were on our second bottle of wine).  All in all we enjoyed ourselves and ate all of the food. The end price was actually pretty good for all we got. We'll definitely be going there again.

Listen, I love exposed brick and bars with lots of atmosphere.  Dandelion Market has all that, with a rack of shoes on one wall, an elevated seating area, and of course this mythical upstairs area that we didn't get to see since it was 6 pm on a week night.  Folks at the bar were drinking and having a great time; our party of three grabbed a table to order some of their small plates and see what all the fuss was about.  The beer list is very good, but - as my husband said - "there's nothing on here I've never tried before," and I felt the whole list was a tick expensive.  I'll be back on a Monday night for their $3 drafts.  As for the food, it was disappointing.  I always feel tapas places are overpriced, particularly for vegetarians, and I came away with the same feeling from Dandelion Market.  My husband and I ordered a pesto flatbread, pommes frites, and the "deconstructed" caprese.  The flatbread was completely unmemorable, and the most interesting part of the caprese were the balls of fried mozzarella.  Though the baby greens were limp and boring, a bite of fried mozzy, tomato, and greens was pretty all right.  The pommes frites were disappointing... when I order a $6 plate of pommes frites, I guess I expect more pommes and less frites.  When I surveyed our spread, I had a hard time coming to terms with the fact that I'd just spent $12 on a tiny, average salad and a plate of fries.  Our friend had the mussels, which were much more impressive looking, and I imagine the other meat dishes comported themselves equally well.  Sometimes it sucks to be veg.  Dessert was a salted brownie with caramel drizzle - another completely unmemorable concoction - though our friend ordered the rhubarb crumble, which was the best thing I think all of us tasted the entire evening.  I'll give Dandelion a 3-star for atmo and beer list, but I doubt I'll be eating here again.

Great little spot for a drink.  Been here a few times before going to a play or concert.  Love the calamari one of the best in Charlotte.  The downstairs bar is small, but it is comfortable with great service.  Staff is friendly and memorable.
Great late night spot with good food.  Its american style tapas.  Meaning its not specifically oriented to one cuisine but its a small plate serving where you share and order multiples.

Came here to wait for some friends and went straight to the bar - good selection on beers! bartender was nice and friendly.  Asked her rec on food and she told me wings and the mac and cheese was worth the try... i agree. really good fresh mac and cheese, the wings were good but nothing crazy amazing so was ok on that end.   good after work place if this is what your looking for.

Went to dinner here with some girlfriends while visiting Charlotte. I love the idea of tapas. It's fun to get a bunch of stuff and share. We got the crostini with procuitto, calamari, brussel sprouts and these fried potato balls (cant exactly remember the name of them). Everything was good, I would go back to try more things since I was still kind of hungry after we left.

I love everything about this place. The atmosphere, the menu, the wine selection, right down to their glass water bottles. I am disappointed that they took the fried sage leaves off the menu, but, they have plenty other amazing dishes to make up for it.

This is sort of a cross between a gastropub and a tapas bar, which sounds like it shouldn't work but believe me, it does.  They have a large number of beers on tap and a menu of interesting/innovative takes on pub grub, priced reasonably and served as small plates.  For example, between my wife and me, we had an artisan cheese plate, bacon cheddar sliders, fried calamari and some spicy raw tuna on top of crispy flatbread-like chips as well as two beers each.  Basically this let us try a bunch of awesome stuff without getting too full or breaking the bank.  Everything they served us was good; the star in my opinion was the tuna.  I appreciated the bartender's recommendations for beer, as well - I told him I was in the mood for a lager and wanted to try something new, and he had me taste his recommendation before he served up a full one.  Nice gesture.

I eat out atheist 4 times a week and so do most of my friends...but our main complaint is no food gets us excited anymore  Palm, Mortons you name it.... you name it..     but we went to the Dandelion market tonight and it was terrific ..I kind of stopped posting on Yelp but came back just to mention this place and food that got me excited again...and the service was fantastic. I almost hate writing this because I don't want the place to get to crowded. But trust me try this place I'm sure all the servers are capable and nice, but if you want to assure great service ask for Julie she is great...We had scallops, lamb, Gnocchi and Bruschetta. We had plenty after just three dishes but couldn't stop eating.....again great place and thanks again Julie for great service

Came here for the first time to meet a friend and I must say, it was probably one of the best restaurants I've been to in a long time!   The food was amazing and the change the menu every so often so you have to go back and try every. Prices were very reasonable, and the staff were extremely polite!   Will definitely be returning here soon!

We usually come here for Sunday Brunch. Most of the times the food and service is pretty good. This time however the service was terrible and our food was cold and biscuits were burnt and hard. We sat for 5 minutes without a place setting and nothing to eat our food with.
Try the sliders and tuna tapas. Love the choice in local beer too.

Dinner food is very good ! fried calamari is amazing !!!!! But when went to brunch and the food was greasy and service is always bad I'm giving them 4 stars because I know it's something that can be fixed !

The draft beer selection is great the tapas style menu is a perfect match and the upstairs is a great after work gathering place. But the best thing about this place is the bartender named Siti (sp) he is one of the best in Charlotte.
Duck fat fries are awesome. The torta rustica is good but it has quite a bit of cheese. Service was prompt and friendly.

Let me start by saying. I have only been to this place during the day. Specifically brunch on the weekends. That being said. They do some good stuff. Their brunch menu is fantastic. Short and simple but more than filling and delicious. A great draft beer list for a smaller place along with a bloody mary bar and mimosas galore. Food as always been quick and service friendly. Only downfall... It you can call it that. Would be the "over easy eggs". The yolk was completely cooked through. Now I know how easy it is to overcook an egg I do it practically every morning. That being said. Not a big deal. If you want a great low key brunch. Get here. They do it right.
Not a bad spot for a vegan bite in Charlotte. Though there are few options on the menu. Enjoyed the black bean sliders. Nice staff, and very solid local beer selection.

I love this place! The food is good, creative, and the small plate concept is awesome for share. If you want some place to ho and hsve good conversation with friends, Dandelion Market is the best place! Good wine selection! I suggest the Lamb! Anytime I'm in Charlotte i have to stop by.

Very unique spot! It's cozy with dim lighting. The tapas are delicious!! My boyfriend & I are new to the area and were wandering around for a dinner spot. When we sat down at Dandelion, we didn't realize it was only tapas. We were starving so we weren't thrilled at first. But we ordered 4 and it was plenty! We were stuffed! We each had a glass of wine and our bill was only about $60 so it wasn't too bad. We will definitely go back!!

Came here on a Thursday night without a reservation and we're sat at a one-off table with high-stools upstairs. Wasn't too crowded but packed enough. Beer selection was standard and our waitress was attentive. We ordered four plates - the stuffed sausage poblano, the meatballs, the lamb lollipops and short rib on polenta. Everything was delicious but pretty salty. Our waitress was informative since it was our first time there and attentive. I'd go back again but would just request all the dishes be less salty. Seems to be much more happening on Fridays and Saturdays. Bartender waved goodbye even though we never met him. 2 thumbs up from me!
Fun place for a girls evening. We shared appetizers, enjoyed oversized booths and fun crowd.  Food was amazing and we shared most of it among the girls!
Excellent made from scratch Bloody Marys,  the quiche was two inches high, fluffy, flaky, and delicious and the biscuits are to die for.  A must if you're in the uptown Charlotte area.
Great tapas restaurant. Good food and great prices. Super fun to dance upstairs late night on the weekends.

What a treasure!  Loved absolutely everything I tried & so did everyone in my group.  I tried the deviled eggs, beet salad, Brussel sprouts and had the scallops.  The scallops were the best I have ever had.  They were perfectly cooked and served on s bed of deliciousness!  Others in the group had the mussels, portabella fries and sliders.  All were extremely pleased and we left very pleased with our meal.  I highly recommend!

This place is awesome. I was traveling through, killing time here before a flight out of CLT and the staff was SO nice. They let me keep my luggage safe up front. Zye, the bartender made me feel welcome, as did the doorman bry. If you're ever stuck in downtown charlotte come here and people will take very good care of you. Stupendous beer selection.

Was in Charlotte for a conference and decided to try a tapas style dining experience. Dandelion market far exceeded my expectations for new american style food. Went on a Wednesday evening - no wait or reservation needed at normal dining hours. Atmosphere was a bit dark, but then again, I believe this doubles as a night scene/bar so that is acceptable. I want to start the discourse on food by saying the waitress we had was outstanding!!! She was knowledgeable about the menu, was able to provide good suggestions from personal experience and was attentive to the table's needs. The food was excellent and some dishes were very unique (I like trying new things). Will return if I'm in Charlotte again.

Dandelion Market is one of my favorite tapas restaurants in the QC and on my latest trip I enjoyed the market to its fullest. We wen't out with a couple friends and took full advantage of plate sharing and four hungry appetites.   We ended up splitting 20 plates by the end of the night which was just a few plates shy of breaking our personal group record of 28 plates while dining at Good Food on Montford a couple weeks prior. We started the night out by getting the Charcuterie Board, the Artisanal Cheese Board, and the Vietnamese Spring Rolls. I can't say much about the spring rolls other than they we're cold and without the accompanying slightly spicy sauce to dip them in they might not be worth recommending. The cheese board had a small assortment of salty, creamy, and savory cheeses that started off the evening on the right track and paired well with the sliced meats on the charcuterie board.    Next we dove into the Baked Potato Croquettes, the Fried Pickles, Black Bean Sliders, and the Moroccan Lamb Kabobs. The croquettes were so incredibly delicious that we ended up ordering a second plate. The little fried balls of aged cheddar, Beeler's bacon, and scallion cream are the type of thing worth making a pilgrimage out of. The fried pickles were sliced not speared and had a great crunch that made them stand out against some of Charlottes other greasy and flimsy fried pickle alternatives. The black bean sliders were largely thought of as ok but didn't leave us with any notable impression.   Then we dove into the next section with the Butter Sauteed Sea Scallops and the Pan Seared Ahi Tuna. The tuna was the clear favorite between the two dishes but the scallops still held their own and were worth recommending.   The Cherry Glazed Lamb Lollipops, Dando Ribs, Grilled Chicken Wings, Grilled Steak Skewers, Sausage Stuffed Poblano Pepper, Market Mac & Cheese, and the Zucchini Ribbon Pasta finished off the night. The lamb lollipops were delicious but the cherry glaze that accompanied them taste like cough syrup and was definitely a down side for the dish. The dando ribs and the chicken wings were juicy and tender but couldn't hold their weight against the crowned king of the night. The grilled steak skewers are marinated in an asian brown sugar soy sauce and a sweet chili sauce. The steak skewers melt in your mouth and create such a euphoric feeling you might end up ordering several more :)  The Mac & Cheese came with spiral noodles, a crumb topping, and plenty of CHEESE, CHEESE, and more CHEESE!!!! The Mac & Cheese was made even better by adding the sausage stuffed poblano pepper... it created a very high-end cheesy Hamburger Helper. The zucchini pasta was the only non-fried healthy vegetable plate we ordered for the night and probably a wise decision given the immense amount of meat we had eaten at that point.   No dinner is complete without dessert so we ordered a brownie sundae, an apple fritter, and a chocolate cake (to-go). The triple chocolate brownie sundae was delicious and one of the few things that should be noted as not a small plate... I repeat... this is plenty big enough to share between two people. The apple fritter left us wanting more but the accompanying ice cream made for a nice pairing between the hot apple cinnamon and the cold ice cream. The chocolate cake was topped with ganache but largely came across as an average piece of chocolate cake.   Dandelion Market is an incredible tapas restaurant and every trip leaves us counting down the days until we make a return visit. Check them out and let me know what you think :)

Seems like more of a bar than a restaurant.  I hear their tapas are good so I will have to go back for that.  I had brunch there and it was alright.  They had some unique combinations but I wasn't wowed.  I will have to go back to drink.
Nice place, do not get the brussel sprouts if you like crunchy and tasty sprouts.  Short ribs were good but the waitress talked up the brussel sprouts and they just weren't good.

Great spot in downtown Charlotte to try different small plates and share with others. Think before you order! Some plates are huge like fries and Mac n cheese but others a very small-shrimp and grits. Servers will stagger your order so you can enjoy the food and not feel like you have to eat everything at once. Upstairs eating area is more favorable to me with dim lighting a more of a relaxed atmosphere. Great beer selection as well!

Great for the small plate dinners and entrees alike. Dandy turns into something awesome at night with 2 floors of bars and plenty of local craft brews. Bartenders are exceptional at making your drink magically appear before you. Late night, get a basket you pomme frites, and you can thank me later.

This is my favorite style of restaurant because I LOVE small plates and drinks. They do everything right here and the atmosphere is rustically romantic. I highly recommend the chicken wings and fries to go with whatever cocktail calls your name.
Setously guys this might be the most authentic fake Irish bar in the greater charlotte area.

Had a work trip to Charlotte so I asked the hotel about any places it would be good to have a dinner. This was the prime recommendation.   My coworker and I easily found the place as it was very distinctive from the outside. When we were seated, the atmosphere felt much like where people can come have a meal and some drinks. I wanted to try their tomato soup with grilled cheese but that was in their lunch menu. The place has separate menus for lunch and dinner.. Both worth a visit for.   The variety was wonderful and the portions are perfect for sharing multiple plates. We got the ribs (KC style), a crab cake and zucchini pasta. Loved the crab cake and ribs. The zucchini was okay. The other table had dessert that looked to be a delight. We, unfortunately, were too full to indulge.   They had a $15 dollar wine offer that night. Perfect for groups. I got a beer and coworker got a white wine that she said was delicious.   All in all, I loved the experience and the food. Service is amazing and food is up to par.   Will come back for the lunch if I come visit Charlotte again!

Food is great, everything we ordered came out very quickly and was delicious. I especially liked the prosciutto crostinis. The Resturant itself has dim lighting and brick walls which creates a nice ambiance. And we had great service. Also for brunch there's a make your own Bloody Mary bar.

This place is awesome.  The atmosphere is unassuming but the food is not. I had several plates from cheese to lamb with candied cherrys and even a carrot cake and even some scallops to top my night off.   Amazing food - decent prices and a relaxed atmosphere make this a new place in Charlotte that's near the top of my list.

Great atmosphere and really good options for brunch. I made my brunch from small plates and my only complaint is that I asked for crispy bacon and it came out less fine than I prefer but otherwise food is good. My honey had the hangover hash and it was excellent. Service could be slightly faster but overall great experience.

Dinner is all tapas and they're soooo good! Lots of good varieties of food. Must try the Mac b cheese & the black bean burger sliders. Really cool environment as well. Can't wait to go back!! Also, reasonably priced!

Wow. Gross. Ew. Steak skewers were charred black. Pomme frites were from Applebee's. French Quarter mussels tasted like a Red Baron frozen supreme pizza with less flavour. The scallops were delicious and the only saving grace. What a travesty of a restaurant.
Great bar - Friendly patrons, friendly bartender. Exposed brick inside, very relaxed vibe. Nice selection of beers on tap-- I enjoyed a pint of the Stone Arrogant Bastard.

Tonight we dined at the Dandelion Market prior to our showing of the Nucracker at Blumenthal Performing Art Center.  The restaurant is perfectly situated for a short walk after eating to attend a show there.  Anyway, we had reservations and the table was ready for us as soon as we walked in the door.  There were 9 of us eating.  We had three young boys with us (7 and 8 year olds) and were told the place was family friendly.  While it was quite a bit noisy in there at least the ends of the tables were able to converse, talking to someone from one end to the other was not an option though.  After ordering our drinks we waited a little bit for them to come around but that was really the only serving snafu.  The beer menu is quite good and the pints are priced reasonably well.  We opted to bring our own bottle of wine with us for those drinking that (the corking fee was $20).  All of the bottles are priced at $25 so even that is not too bad.   The food we ordered was really good.  The calamari I ordered was a good sharable size with plenty to go around.  we actually ordered two for our table but unfortunately one of our orders was given to another table but we had so much food we really didn't miss it, the waitress was apologetic for the mistake.  We order the pom frites which were really good as well, large baskets of them, we ordered two baskets of these and honestly it was too much even for the 9 of us.    The main courses were equally good.  I had the mussels which I was told was a full pound and I believe it.  My wife ordered the lamb lollipops and she really enjoyed it.  Others in our group said their food was good as well.  All told it was an excellent place.  I will return to try other dishes.  Really the only reason I knocked a star off was because of the serving snafu and the level of noise but it isn't a very big place.  I would certainly recommend checking it out.

I came here around 7pm on a Friday night and seating for two was immediate. The place had a rustic but upscale and trendy feel which I enjoyed. I had the Mac and cheese as my entree, and It was excellent! Definitely one of the best I've had in any restaurant. The top had a breading which added a crunch to it, and the inside was deliciously creamy. The waiter was attentive and prompt as well.   Although I did not stay for drinks, I did check out the upstairs bar location which looked very fun. The friend I was eating with said that at night the large wooden table in the center is hoisted up into the air for more floor space - a very neat concept.   Overall, I definitely would recommend a visit to Dandelion Market for a quieter, cool dinner spot. And also for that delicious Mac and cheese!

Went for snackies and drinks and was waited on by the nicest Irish bartender (Wolf???) ever. The beer taps were very nice and diverse and the tapas were equally diverse and scrumptious.  We had the calamari rings, and I think they're the best I've ever had, period.  We also had two other tapas but I can't remember (like I said nice craft brews) what they were.  I do remember we all commented on how delicious they were. The bar area is very nice, nice bar with "angles" so it's easier for a group of 4 to sit at the bar and see each other and talk. Nice decor, good lunch menu selections.  Would definitely want to be a regular here if we lived in Charlotte.

My boyfriend and I went here on a Wednesday night, atmosphere was great. We love the simple arrangements of tables and brick walls. We came to Charlotte  from the Orlando area (suprisingly foodie  friendly ), and were  expecting  to be bowled over by the food. Sadly, this wasn't  the case.  I ordered  a drink that had some fancy name but was basically  a gin ricky.  I had to send it back for more St. Germaine because it was tasteless. We ordered the cheddar  sliders which were flavorful but the bun was so dry it crumbled in your hand. Then the mussels, meh is the only thing I can say. I'm used to there being at least an inch of delicious creamy soup with giant amounts of bread. I get it, tapas. But seriously, 2 little croutons each? No worries, they were pretty bland regardless. Then the bizarre greenbeans came.  Basically take some regular ol greenbeans  and coat them in bottled sauce.  I thought they'd  be great fried as a finger food as it was tapas  but nope, wet and weird.  Service was fine, not spectacular  but average.  I  wouldn't waste my time here until they correct what's going on in the kitchen.

We were in Charlotte for a tech conference and were exploring the area. This place was such a great find. It was soooo good! The decor was so cute and everything on the menu looked delicious. I got the huevos rancheros which was just amazing. Everyone was really happy with their food.

Get the grilled cheese.  Don't think about the calories.  just get it.  Thick crusty well buttered artisanal bread with gooey insanely yummy cheese and a proper thick tomato soup, none of that watery from a can drips all over you soup.  My boyfriend actually stole some of my soup with his fork over the table and it didn't leave the fork, that thick.  He had the most monstrous chicken salad on a croissant sandwich i'd ever seen.  I don't know what dressing they use on their salads but it was yummy.   We met up for lunch uptown during the work week and it was well worth it.  The service was surprisingly quick and the food wasn't very expensive.   We didn't get a beer (kind of frowned upon mid afternoon during working hours!) but we have been many times for a pint and their selection is diverse and full of craft brews.  What I love most about The Dando is that the lower bar and the upper bar have completely different feels to them.  The lower bar is more small restaurant/pub and the upstairs is perfectly suited for a night out with the girls and saturday nights.  forgot to add: for those of you who work in uptown, they have a punch card for lunch!

Went on a weekday around 10am so they didn't have brunch kind of disappointed. Got a mimosa anyway a champagne flute holds more than the glass they gave me, waste of money.   Chicken salad sandwich was good though.

this place is awesome! was in charlotte for a conference and ended up going back to this place several times. dandelion market has great food and is fun place to go if you want to try a bunch of GREAT food.  on our last night in charlotte, we showed up on a sunday night eight people in our group. with no available tables downtown stairs, the staff happily opened up the top floor for us which felt like a private party. the atmosphere here is adorable and i will forever recommend 'the dando' to anyone visiting charlotte.

This place was great.  Nice and cozy.  We had several items for dinner.  We had spinach dip, calamari, steak skewers and crab cake.  Brownie with ice cream for dessert.  Monday was $3 pints! Definitely going to go back again.  Service was friendly and helpful.  No complaints at all loved it

Came here with a client for a dinner with 12 people. We ordered the entire menu (they offer this and it comes in waves) and it was INCREDIBLE. My favorites were the lamb lollipops, sweet and spicy green beans and the short rib. It was a wonderful first experience to get to try nearly everything so I know what to focus on when I go and have to actually pay!  There was a good selection of wine and beer and service was exceptional. Highly recommended!

I recently spent a lovely evening at Dandelion Market enjoying some very good food. We had the entire second floor to ourselves and the service was fantastic.   It's a rustic looking pub, old exposed wood and brick with dim lighting and a cozy atmosphere. When I heard we would be dining at the "Dandelion Market" I was expecting a more open and bright place, more like a farmers market vibe. I was instantly reminded of the bars in Dublin at Temple Bar, which I believe is exactly what they were trying for.   They had a good sized menu of small plates for dinner, also some sandwiches and other items for lunch. I tried a bite or two of the fried pickles, grilled steak skewers, ale simmered sausage bites, tiger prawns, and the santa fe corn. I heard the market mac n cheese, baked potato croquettes, and the prosciutto crostini were all very good as well.   The service was terrific all night. We were there for about three hours and the servers kept our glasses full and made sure we were well fed.   I can't wait till the next time I'm in Charlotte and can try brunch at Dandelion Market, it sounds delicious.

I wish I could write two reviews for Dandelion Market-one for the upstairs and one for the downstairs because it was two completely different vibes.  I absolutely loved the downstairs area and wish I could have stayed there all night. Open seats at the bar on a Saturday night along with a friendly bartender with some football playing is all I really need in life. It had a chill vibe, exposed brick walls and  music playing just loud enough to enjoy but you could hear another speak and just seemed like a cozy atmosphere. One of my friends I was with is pregnant and the bartender Amanda whipped up a special alcohol free concoction for her. Can I please just stay downstairs forever enjoying my Shocktop?  The answer-no. We had a large party and wanted to sit down to eat and our table was upstairs  I really wanted to love this place but the upstairs kinda killed it for me. I didn't even know there was an upstairs area but when we got there, I wanted to go into the corner and crawl into a fetal position. It was like every 25 yr old hipster in town was there and every guy seemed to have either a vintage blazer and John Edwards hair (or sometimes both--eek!)  It wasn't a place to eat, it was a bar area! They had  large booths and I was sitting on the outside and kept getting elbowed by some randoms doing shots. Server was nice but they seemed to be out of alot of stuff by 9P. I got the flatbread and house salad which were both ok but nothing to write home about. The flatbread seemed more like a mini pizza than flatbread and the salad had about seven to eight pieces of lettuce with some cranberries and dressing. I could find a better salad elsewhere for $6. I just wanted to finish my meal so I could get the hell back downstairs.   I'll probably check out Dandelion again for lunch during the week or an after work drink but no way will I be venturing into hipster hell upstairs again!

If you haven't been to this restaurant in Charlotte, YOU MUST! Huge menu and tapas style, and I have never gotten anything I didn't like! It is a great dinner place for Friday nights before a night out on the town! Up stairs bar get rowdy late at night, so I wouldn't plan a romantic late night dinner here on a weekend, but evening would be perfect!
This place has amazing foods.  From the fried pickles to the lamb to the skewers to the chicken wings to the stuffed poblano peppers and more. All were amazing.
Great atmosphere. The lamb is great. Wait staff very attentive. Good beer selection on tap.

I love variety packs, samplers, flights, combos, mixed offerings in general. That's part of the reason why I dig tapas-style places.  Nothing pleases me more than tasting some of this and some of that.  The other part of the reason is that my dining philosophy is generally if you can make it at home with no unreasonable effort, you should just make it at home.  Now try making a tapas menu at home.  It'll take forever and it probably won't be very good.  So for me tapas/small plates = the perfect restaurant dining experience. I thoroughly enjoyed dinner at "dando".  Little plates of calimari, mac and cheese, ribs and a couple of other things were very tasty.  The marinated olives were a bit on the salty side.  The beer selection was of course very satisfying as well, I got a delightful, fragrant Belgian. We went back for brunch one day and honestly that was less impressive.  The fluffy fritatta was tasty, the waffle was just ok.  The coffee was not piping hot. I'd definitely come back for dinner, but it looks like my brunch search is still on.

I took a few clients here while on a business trip to NC and it was incredible!  I feel like sharing food with clients is a great way to form a bond.  Who wouldn't want to bond over food?!  The few highlights for me were the calamari, brussel sprouts and gnocci and fried pickles. We ordered about 3 items each and were stuffed.

This is almost 2 different places, but they're both great. The food during the day is fantastic - tapas and small plates to share, but everything is so delicious. Come for brunch, lunch, or dinner and you can't go wrong. After dark, the upstairs portion turns into a dance club and it's a ton of fun.

The Ahi tuna salad sandwich is one of the best sandwiches I've ever had. I get it with tomato soup almost every time I forget to pack my lunch for work. I know I'm in a rut, but it's a rut I'm happy to be in.  I've also been for dinner several times and LOVED it. I took my mom when I first moved to Charlotte and she asks to go back every time she visits.  I've never had anything I didn't like here. I would recommend the scallops and the sweet potato gnocchi in particular. Its definitely a little pricey but since it's small plates it's easy to keep the cost down if you just want to sample a couple things.   My only complaint is that they have a lunch card (I think buy 9 lunch entrees get the 10th free?) and I was about 6 lunches in before I found out about the card. They also never ask if you have one so I always forget and have only had it stamped once. If you work nearby and go for lunch a lot, take advantage of this! The staff probably won't tell you about it.

Nothing special. Food was over cooked. Wouldn't recommend any omelette. Only reason they get 2 stars is because service was good and they comped my omelette off. Went to 5 church and everything was better. $10 bottomless sangrias and $12 bottomless mimosas at 5 church.

We chose the Dandelion for its proximity to my daughter's hotel where her team is staying and for its varied menu selections as she's a vegetarian and we're not. We were promptly seated: the restaurant was busy but not overly crowded after all it was Tuesday after Christmas.  It would have helped us choose if their online menu and website had indicated that they were a small plates joint and therefore the prices were expensive for the small portions. In disclosure the waitress did tell us it was small plates after she seated us.   Short ribs, mac&cheese, a few different salads, lamb lollipops--it was excellent food all around.  The problem was the poor service.  Having to ask for a replacement napkin several times before it rang a bell. And dessert. It took at least 15 minutes for the waitress to return and apologize that there was no tiramisu then another fifteen before the single dessert appeared.  Lots of waiting and feeling ignored tonight with nobody visible to flag down. Good food is a large part of the experience but lousy service can wreck it.

Excellent quality small plates with wide selection of local beers. Great atmosphere and attentive servers as well.   We went on a Sunday evening (7-ish) and had no problem getting a window table even though the place was busy.   The waiter recommended 2-3 tapas per person. We selected 5 including brussels sprouts, hummus, shrimp and grits, chorizo fundido, and fried green caprese. We're not big eaters so 5 was the perfect number...six would've pushed us over the edge of comfort!  Our favorite was the hummus, topped with black olive tapenade, crisped garbonzos, and served with soft pita wedges. The hummus had just enough heat to make it interesting.   The S&G came in the form of a grit-cake with 2 huge grilled shrimp on top. We loved the taste but the grits had cream cheese mixed in so were definitely on the heavy side.  The Chorizo Fundido was more like a queso but was spicy and flavorful.   The FGC were hearty and paired with fresh mozzarella slices. Very good!  I only tried one of the brussels, which I don't care for, so I can't comment on how it compares.  In summary, my wife and I decreed that this is our new "go to place!" You should check it out!

My wife and I were in Charlotte for her business trip and we went to Dandelion Market for an early anniversary dinner. We had a great time and a nice meal.  We walked in around 5:30 on a Wednesday and were seated right away; the restaurant was maybe 1/4 full. It has a nice ambiance: romantic lighting, brick walls. It's a nice atmosphere for a cozy, romantic dinner.  Their wine list online and on the printed menu at the restaurant is wine by the bottle only, and each bottle is $25. This turned us off from going there for lunch, but it needn't have, since it turned out they had a chalkboard on one wall with a selection of wines by the glass. They also have a good beer selection, including Bell's Two-Hearted, my favorite beer.  We ordered off their dinner menu, which is all tapas (small plates), between about $6 - $12 each. With tapas, we like to order one or two at a time, up to about four total for the two of us. We started with their Artisanal Cheese Board, which came with 3 really nice cheeses, apricot preserves, honeycomb, almond cake/loaf of some sort, and some pita bread wedges. It was a nice enough cheese tray and went well with our Pinot Noir. Our next two tapas were the Shrimp and Grits and Grilled Steak Skewers. The grits were actually two grit cakes, topped with goat cheese--interesting and very nice. The steak skewers were cooked medium rare (there's no choice in the matter) and straight-forward, but very good. We finished the meal with Stuffed Poblano Pepper--stuffed with sausage and cheese, topped with a cream sauce--that was just fantastic. Easily the highlight of the meal. If we went back, I think we'd be tempted to get two of those as an entree.  For dessert, we were told they had had an unexpected run on desserts this week, but were supplementing the 2 house-made desserts they had left with a couple choices from a nearby bakery. We got the Oreo Cheesecake from the bakery, and were not disappointed--they chose bakeries well.  Overall, we had a great, filling romantic dinner--with a bottle of wine--for a pretty great price. Every thing we got was either good or great, and our waitress was great. We were so happy that, when my wife stayed an extra day to finish her trip, she went back for her final dinner in Charlotte. We'll definitely try to make a trip our next time in town.

Unfortunately disappointing food. Ordered take-out from here and should have followed my instinct to trash the entire meal, which reeked of old fryer oil. The calamari was barely edible, fried pickles over-cooked and the source of the old oil smell, and the black bean sliders uninspiring from the slider itself, to the dry flat "bread" it was served on and the accompanying bland tomato bland.

This is my first time coming to Dandelion for food - I have been several times for drinks at night. My friends and I went to Dandelion Market on March 26th around 11am for brunch. We had a party of about 10 people and a few were running late. There was no wait, but since we couldn't be seated until our entire party arrived, I grabbed a quick soft drink at the bar. This was easily transferred over to my bill once seated.  We were sat upstairs at the long table that is normally hanging from the ceiling at night. I had the quiche of the day, which contained sausage and vegetables, and had fresh fruit on the side. In addition, I ordered a chocolate chip waffle. I thought that the wait for food was a little long, but maybe I was just hungry. Ha! All the food was good and I felt that it was a nice quantity for the price.  I've been to several brunch places in Charlotte and Dandelion is one of the better ones. When I come again I will probably get the Little Italy Omelette. One of my friends ordered it and it looked DELICIOUS.

After reading all of the positive reviews about Dandelion Market on Yelp and seeing it busy every time we walked by the establishment, we finally decided to give it a try this past Saturday night.  Knowing that it's seemingly always busy on weekend nights, I called about a reservation.  Sadly, they didn't take any for parties under 8.  We decided to give it a shot and wait.    We showed up Saturday around 7:30.  I was surprised and happy to see that there was nobody waiting for a table by the hostess stand.  I informed one of the two hostesses there that we wanted a table for two.  She told me it was an hour to and hour and a half wait.  I looked around.  Yes, all of the tables were full...but there was nobody waiting for one either.  She then informed me that there was a bar area upstairs and we could sit up there if we wanted to.  I wasn't aware there was an upstairs at that point, but I was grateful for the additional seating.  We walked upstairs and found another large room with a long bar and a lot of additional tables.  The first thing we both noticed was how incredibly sticky the floor was.  It was like hundreds of sloppy drunk people spilled their drinks and nobody bothered to clean it up.  It reminded both of us of our college days, but that was for the small local bars when you don't care about cleanliness and are just out for a good time.    The bar only had random single seats, no two seats together.  There were two empty tables off to the side in the corner.  They weren't great, had awful lighting, and didn't provide much atmosphere as the rest of the (sticky) room.  Since it was our only option, we decided to sit in one.  Not long after, we were approached by a server informing us that we had to put our name on the waiting list for that table.  Interesting, since the hostess informed us that we could sit "in the bar area upstairs" if there were open seats.  And, if these were open tables, why wasn't anybody on the hour-to-an-hour-and-a-half waiting list being seated in them?    Attitudes from both the hostess and a server?  Sticky, unclean floors?  An hour and a half wait for...what?  That was enough for us.  The pretension was astounding.  We walked downstairs, passed three girls at the hostess doing nothing, and proceeded right out the door.  Nobody said anything to us, and they certainly didn't want to hear what I had to say.  Yes, my review is not about the food at the Dandelion Market, but it IS about the cleanliness and customer service, two qualities that I find very important in restaurants, both of which greatly affect my experience...and I thought you should know, too.  I guess Dandelion Market didn't want my money that evening, so I dropped $100 for the two of us elsewhere and we had a great dining experience.

I went back with a large group, and found a completely different restaurant. Actually, it wasn't so much that the restaurant had changed so much as the atmosphere now made sense. It was a Thursday night and we arrived at 7pm - early enough to beat the bar crowd. We were also seated upstairs, where the tables are a little farther from the bar, so that helped with the noise problem. But I think what really helped me was the realization that this is not the place for a quiet dinner; boisterous groups are a much better fit.  Also a plus, a large group means lots of pitchers of beer. That means trying four or five different brews. When a place has 25 beers on tap, you have to step up to the challenge.  There being ten of us, we had just enough to make the one-of-everything-for-$200 work. It made us all feel pretty swanky. Handling that many plates could be quite the ordeal, but with a couple of fun waiters the chaos was enjoyable. Some of the tapas, such as the cheese plate, are easily split amongst 10 people. But some are not. How do you share a house salad? Any ideas? I never saw how that was resolved, because a constant stream of food kept pulling my attention. The amount of food was just what the 10 of us could handle. The one-of-everything selection probably works for 10-12 Maybe 14 if you aren't too hungry. But there is nothing to stop a larger group from ordering the $200 deal and then adding extra plates of their favorites.  In the end, I probably tried two thirds of their plates. Some I loved (artichoke hearts, flatbreads) some I didn't (lamb popsicles) but I'll know for next time. Speaking of next time, I will certainly be back. I'll just know that this is a place best experienced with many many friends.

Thoroughly enjoyed the atmosphere and food at this place. The boyfriend and I wandered in on a Sunday afternoon in need of snacks and libations. After looking at the menu here, we wondered if he'd be okay in a baseball cap, so we decided to walk by and feel.    The place was pretty empty, so we sidled up to the bar and ordered a pitcher of Abita Triple Haze, a more high-octane version of my favorite summer sipper, Purple Haze. Did I mention this place has an awesome beer selection?   For food, we chose the grilled lamb lollipops with black cherry, greens and feta vinaigrette, along with the proscuitto crostini topped with fig preserves and caramelized onions. Both were great! The lamb was a bit fruity for me (in fact I probably would have preferred it sans cherry), but then I ordered a dish with fruit. The crostini was a really nice balance of sweet, salty and savory. I definitely wanted to come back and try more food here.  Also, the service was super casual and friendly, as were the regulars hanging around. The bf mentioned he's new to town and everyone chimed with suggestions of things to do, good delivery, must-visit restaurants, etc.   In all, this was a great place for afternoon hanging. Can't wait to return!

I wanted Blue Finn, my friend wanted Pita Pit...Dandelion Market was our happy medium. Before I agreed on this place, I had to scope out the menu. I saw tapas...lots of delicious tapas!   While waiting for my friend to arrive, I decided to try the beer special. A grapefruit wheat beer poured over a simple orange chili syrup. Yummmm. The combination of citrus and heat was refreshing with just the right amount of heat. The waitress informed me that this particular beer was not in stores just yet and they had the exclusive opportunity to showcase it before it was introduced to the public. When my friend arrived, she tasted the beer without the syrup because she doesn't like spice. She enjoyed the beer and we both sipped on this tasty grapefruit beverage as we enjoyed our dinner.  Ok so let's get to the tapas. The menu is broken down into sections by appetizers, surf, turf, etc. Deserts aren't listed because they vary by the day.
